BLUF: An adversary may breach or otherwise leverage a mobile network operator's (MNO's) roaming partners or their service partners to gain access to subscriber's services or obtain information about that subscriber from their home network.
An adversary may install a compromised image in the image repository to achieve persistence.

A adversary positioned in an operator network may send an SMS delivery location query that will bypass the SMS home router of another operator, and which will allow to get the location of the user device.
An adversary may employ a false base station to bid down (downgrade) the victim UE to a less secure Radio Access Network in order to exploit vulnerabilities in that network.
An adversary may gain access to an operator's roaming database (IR.21), which can reveal the critical network assets of both the operator and its roaming partners.
An adversary may query the Network Repository Function (NRF) to discover restricted   Network Function (NF) services to further target that NF.
An adversary may discover Software Defined Network (SDN) flow information, which could then open opportunity for lateral movement and unauthorized changes in the network.
An adversary may use the compromised SDN controller or Control plane API to modify network flow rules, or traffic management policies.
An adversary may compromise a vSwitch in an SDN network to manipulate the network traffic  or cause denial of service
Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by modifying a network device's Virtual Network Function Configuration.
Adversary may be able to break out of VM/Container to host to compromise co-resident tenant VM/Container for discovery and exfiltration and host-based privilege escalation.
An adversary may be able to read memory registers to discover privileged information such as local password comparison, encryption key etc.
An adversary may use various telecom protocols for Command and Control (C2) to/from compromised MNO roaming partner network
An adversary may use local administrative privileges to bypass network controls responsible for access controls and software to achieve persistence.

An adversary may implant rootkits in the Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI) that will hide the presence of programs, files, network connections, services, drivers, and other system components.
An adversary may implant malware in the Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI) that will load during the pre-boot sequence to achieve persistence.

An adversary may use a device (user or base station) to replay registration requests with a valid Subscription Concealed Identifier (SUCI) in order to degrade network availability to other device users.
An adversary, such as an insider to the MNO or vendor, could install a malicious NF into the core network, in order to launch other attacks or get access to information.

Technique Name: Base Station flood with fictitious access requests
BLUF: An adversary transmits large number of access requests over random Access CHannel (RACH) to degrade the ability of legitimate UE to obtain access from the gNB. May be done via a compromised UE or a fake UE
An adversary transmits radio signals to degrade reception and demodulation of signals to the UE or gNB/eNB.

Technique Name: Redirection of Traffic via User Plane Network Function
BLUF: An adversary may divert user plane traffic for one or more UEs via a user-plane function, to monitor user data.

Technique Name: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
BLUF: An adversary-controlled AMF registers itself in the UDM as the serving network for a victim’s UE, enabling further attacks like fraud or the retrieval of the UE’s subscription data.

Technique Name: Unauthorized access to Network Exposure Function (NEF) via token fraud
BLUF: An adversary controlling an (external) Application Function (AF) presents a fraudulent OAuth access token to access Network Exposure Function (NEF) services.
Adversary can track a device (get cell-level location) by listening for the same device ID being sent to the network.
An adversary may alter network signaling so as to disable encryption over the radio interface, thus allowing for eavesdropping of user data or signaling on that interface.
An adversary controlling a user-plane function (gNB or UPF) disrupts user traffic by assigning the new traffic a TEID already in use.
Adversary may use non-5G functional remote communication interfaces (SNMP/RPC, SSH) to change host configuration to enable host compromise.
Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.
An adversary may use CI/CD tools to gain access to production hosts/VNFs for discovery, data exfiltration and for deployment of lateral movements tools.
An adversary may use privileged accounts of valid, role-based accounts for management services to gain access to network elements.
An adversary may use a fake or compromised container management controller to deploy fake VNFs to collect information from the network.
An adversary may use an NFVI controller to gain access to data from a suspended or stopped VNF to extract sensitive information.
An adversary running a malicious Virtual Network Function (VNF) may identify network resources co-resident on the same physical host.

Technique Name: Malicious privileged container VNF Shared Resource Access
BLUF: An adversary may compromise a target Virtual Network Function (VNF) to gain unauthorized access to the data from the underlying resources shared with other VNFs.

Technique Name: Malicious co-tenancy  exploit of NFVI (Network Slice)
BLUF: Adversaries may gain unauthorized access to information via  a Virtual Network Function (VNF) shared for service designed for two different slices.

Adversaries may use a less secure slice to gain access to information in a more secure slice that uses the VNF (Common VNF) built on common infrastructure to misuse resources allocated to target VNFs or slice.

An adversary may use compromised container management SW (or account) in MANO domain to gain access to target VNFs and its resources for unauthorized access to resources/data of another slice in NFVI or resource exhaustion of target application resulting in denial of service.
Adversaries may sniff network traffic to capture information about 5G environment, control and user plane data including authentication material, equipment identifiers.
Adversary may use compromised virtualized network elements to (vSwitch, Vrouter, Virtual Firewalls) to span traffic to sniffing port for access to user plane and control plane data.
Adversaries may gain unauthorized access to a Hardware Security Module (HSMs) to sign  keys and/or other derived key material that can be used to achieve additional goals.
An adversary may compromise the Equipment Identity Register (EIR) function and add new equipment, modifies status (ok vs. stolen or prohibited) of mobile device.
An adversary-controlled UE may send high volumes of signaling messages to core network functions in order to cause a denial of service.
An adversary exploits interconnection/interworking between MNOs to obtain information about roaming user sessions or commit fraud.
An adversary may use scanning tools to discover 5G core network related information (identifiers).
Adversaries may scan operator network to discover network services
An adversary may compromise network separation controls to gain access to one or more of the 5G security zones or networks.

An adversary aims to destroy, expose, alter, disable, steal, or gain unauthorized access to physical assets such as infrastructure, hardware, or interconnection, affecting Quality of Service (QoS) or service availability.
An adversary targets unprotected cables and junction boxes in order to disrupt service.
An adversary uses unrestricted access to exploit, damage, or destroy Radio Access hardware that lack adequate security

An adversary may seek physical access to isolated/remote edge servers using covert methods of entry with the intent to damage or destroy edge computing facilities, gaining unauthorized access at system level as an entry point to all hosted resources, theft of data on local storage, vandalism, and sabotage.
An adversary accesses a shared site, or remote location, with intent to steal valuable materials (such as copper, batteries, and fuel) for resale.
An adversary in the core network exploits signaling protocols to obtain the location of the UE.
An adversary may act as an adversary-in-the-middle (AITM) between two mobile network operators to enable activities like network sniffing (FGT1040) or transmitted data manipulation (FGT1565.002).
An adversary may discover the permanent subscriber identifier via various means
An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the home network of the UE.
An adversary may intercept the UE permanent identifier (SUPI) from a UE that is bid down to a less secure protocol.
An adversary may non-cooperatively geolocate a UE from UE radio signals externals.
An adversary may elicit location reports from UE that is bid down to less secure format or passively observes location reports from UE employing null encryption.
An adversary may eavesdrop on unencrypted subscriber data on the air interface.
An adversary may position itself on the radio interface, to support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Technique Name: Consume data allocation to deny or degrade service
BLUF: A malicious app consumes subscriber data allocation so as to deny or degrade service to that UE

Technique Name: Trigger fraud alert to deny service
BLUF: An adversary may trigger a fraud alert by sending fake registrations on behalf of a given UE
An adversary may alter the subscriber profile  to achieve fraud, via SBI (Service Based Interfaces) or OA&M interfaces.
An adversary controlling a Network Function (NF) or slice can gain access to a different network slice data by interacting with other NFs.
An adversary may guess the identifier of a different network slice, which allows for follow-on behaviors against that slice that require that identifier.
An adversary in a roaming partner operator may send altered service usage for a given UE to the home operator of that UE.
Adversary may clone a SIM card (namely the IMSI, credential stored therein) and use it fraudulently to obtain telecom service at the expense of the user of the device with that legitimate SIM card

An adversary with access to Non-Service Based Interfaces (Non-SBI) network nodes (including routers/switches/load balancers) may position themselves in order to  support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Adversary with access to a non-Service Based Interface (non-SBI) node or an SBI Network Function (NF), or a function on the roaming/interconnect interfaces, may manipulate or spoof user plane and control plane traffic on that interface without integrity protection, towards a DoS or other behaviors on the UE or an NF.
An adversary may obtain the UE location using radio access or core network
An adversary uses a legitimate access token for a shared Network Function (NF) to get location info of a user of a different slice.

An adversary in the 5G core who  compromised a proxy or middlebox may position themselves between Network Functions (NFs) that are communicating via the Service Based Interfaces (SBI), in order to support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Technique Name: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
BLUF: An adversary controlling a gNB or control plane or user plane core Network Function (NF) may manipulate signaling to result in DoS on one or more UEs.
An adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling to retrieve UE subscription information.
An adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling or parameters to achieve charging/billing fraud where victim is UE or operator itself.
An adversary may get access to several SIM credentials either by physical access to SIM card inventory or by compromising  SIM repository.
An adversary may compromise the operator's SMS Center (SMSC) to collect SMS messages to/from the UEs.
Adversary may compromise the 5G Charging Function (CHF) in order to steal sensitive subscriber call related data/CDRs.
An adversary may geolocate a UE by modifying Non-Access Stratum (NAS) signaling.
An adversary may compromise a component of gNodeB to affect radio network configuration
An adversary may compromise a RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) to affect radio network configuration.
An adversary may compromise an xApp to affect the radio network configuration.
An adversary may compromise an rApp to affect the radio network configuration.
An adversary in control of an Application Function (AF) or a rogue Network Function (NF) can make an API call to obtain the Subscriber Permanent Identifier (SUPI) or other sensitive UE information.
An adversary may manipulate encrypted traffic to achieve redirection of DNS requests sent by the victim UE to the network over the radio interface.
An adversary may piggyback user data within DNS requests, so that the DNS server retrieves the user data for further processing.

Technique Name: False Base Station or Access Point
BLUF: An adversary may purchase, rent, or download software to stand up a fake base station (gNB or gNB emulator) or WiFi access point in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against UEs such as adversary in the middle, denial of service, data interception or manipulation.
An adversary may compromise a network device's integrity capability or configuration in order to exploit the non-integrity protected data communication

An adversary may alter or spoof network signaling so as to enable the NULL integrity algorithm thus allowing for manipulation of user data or signaling over the radio interface, for example to redirect traffic.
Adversary with access to radio interface manipulates user and control plane traffic received on that interface without integrity protection, for example to redirect traffic.

An adversary may exploit weaknesses in Application Programming (API) interfaces on Network Functions (NF) that are exposed to the public, i.e. Internet which exposes those functions to potential adversary compromise of the NF, or disclosure of information.

An adversary may exploit weaknesses in Application Programming (API) interfaces on Network Functions (NF) that are exposed to the public Internet, which exposes those functions to potential adversary denial of service of the NF.

An adversary on a semi-public/roaming partner network may exploit weaknesses in Application Programming (API) interfaces on Network Functions (NF) that are exposed to the semi-public network, i.e. roaming partner network, which can lead to denial of service of the exposed NF.
Adversary may buy, build or steal International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI) catcher to capture IMSI numbers from nearby UEs in a target area.

An adversary may purchase, rent, or download software to acquire a programmable User Equipment (UE) device, in order to pave the way to other follow-on behaviors against the Radio-Access Network (RAN) such as denial of service.

Technique Name: Configurability of False Base Station or Access Point
BLUF: An adversary may obtain software to configure a false base station (gNB or gNB emulator) or WiFi access point in order to enable other Radio Access Network (RAN) follow-on behaviors against UEs such as adversary in the middle or denial of service.

Technique Name: Shared slice common control network function resource exhaustion
BLUF: Adversaries may exhaust common resources of a slice to cause denial of service (service degradation) to all other slices that use the same common resources.
Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating from a MNO by sending it over allowed DNS queries to DNS servers outside the MNO.
An adversary may use Control Plane signaling between operator-internal Network Functions and externally-facing NFs or proxies to exfiltrate data to external endpoints.

Technique Name: Access to cloud infra or MEC
BLUF: An adversary may purchase access to cloud infrastructure or Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) resources that will also be hosting the operator's infrastructure

An adversary may change the configuration of network nodes so as to disable or weaken integrity protection on the network interfaces Non-SBI, SBI and Roaming, thus allowing for transmitted data manipulation.
An adversary may weaken or disable encryption on Non-SBI, SBI, and Roaming interfaces, enabling eavesdropping on user data or signaling.
Adversaries may manipulate service or service delivery mechanisms prior to or while used by a mobile network operator (MNO) for the purpose of data or system compromise.
An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

Adversary send specifically crafted messages from an interconnect/interworking partner against roaming interface to gain access to the service function, e.g. SEPP, or to obtain information from the interworking facing service function.
An adversary may send specially crafted data to the UE over-the-air via the radio interface to execute malicious code.

An adversary may send specially crafted data to the UE's application processor's interface to the baseband API to execute malicious code. The adversary with a position on the UE to communicate to the baseband API may execute malicious code on the baseband processing system.
An adversary may develop exploits that target the UE to execute malicious code.
An adversary may create an operator network to facilitate applying techniques to a victim UE.
An adversary obtains network access through illicit means in order to install instrumentation.
An adversary may send crafted GTP-U packets to the UPF/PGW-U in order to establish an illicit session with a target UE.
An adversary may discover a valid GTP-U TEID in order to apply additional techniques.
An adversary controlled UE may be used to send crafted NAS messages to AMF to crash or slow down the AMF.
An adversary-controlled UE may be used to send a GTP-U packet to UPF/PGW-U with a malicious payload in order to evade UPF/PGW-U routing controls to establish communications with a core NF.
An adversary may send an unsolicited SS7/Diameter message to the core network of a UE that will cause the core network to provide coarse location of the UE.
An adversary may send an unsolicited SS7/Diameter message to the core network of a UE that will cause the core network to provide IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

Technique Name: Radio control manipulation via rogue xApps
BLUF: Malicious xApps may gain unauthorized access to near-RT RIC and E2 nodes, in order to affect Radio Access Network (ran) behavior.
Adversary may jam the wireless backhaul facility to disrupt the ability to connect to the network for all UEs or Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) nodes.

Adversary manipulates User Plane data on Open Fronthaul interface between O-DU and O-RU to re-direct the data to a wrong destination or get discarded by the recipient due to incorrect message parameters.
Adversaries may sniff network traffic to capture information about fronthaul user plane.
An adversary may build an International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI) catcher to capture IMSI numbers from nearby UEs in a target area
An adversary may install or set up a customized core mobile network in a target environment to enable follow-on behaviors.
An adversary may operationalize a customized mobile network in a target environment to enable other follow-on behaviors against UEs.
An adversary may build or develop a silent SMS tool in order to send SMSs to nearby phones in a target area.
An adversary may buy or steal a silent SMS tool in order to send SMSes to nearby phones in a target area.
Adversary sends a spoofed or silent SMS to trigger paging of UE, to retrieve the subscriber profile identifier.
Adversary sends spoofed or silent paging messages to a UE and deduces the UE's location from the responses of that UE
Adversary may gain unauthorized access to machine learning model or database and alters the data to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.

Technique Name: AI/ML training data and prediction poisoning
BLUF: Adversary may use AI/ML training data and prediction poisoning techniques to manipulate the outcomes of a machine learning model for malicious purposes, to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.
Adversaries may manipulate software products or product delivery mechanisms prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.
Adversaries may manipulate hardware components or products prior to deployment in an MNO's production environment for the purpose of data or system compromise.

Technique Name: Unauthorized device on O-RAN fronthaul infrastructure
BLUF: An adversary may attach a device to an O-RAN fronthaul infrastructure in order to disrupt its traffic.
An adversary may buy, steal or download capabilities needed to target network elements and User Equipment.
An adversary may obtain radio network function needed to attack target victim UEs.
Adversary controlled fake base station transmits crafted broadcast messages to prevent legitimate UEs to connect to network.

Technique Name: Covert Exfiltration of Data Via DNS Request
BLUF: An adversary may move targeted data and remain undetected during the exfiltration process by using DNS requests.
Adversary  may change the main clock source of PTP in a legitimate gNB to achieve Denial of Service on RAN.
An adversary may flood an external interface to cause a denial of service to the SMO.

Technique Name: Modify Data on SMO external interfaces
BLUF: Adversary modifies data in transit between Service Management and Orchestration (SMO) and external service to disrupt O-RAN network operations.
Adversaries may intercept exports of local logs on unsecured external interface to extract sensitive information.
Rogue xApp sends spoofed ARP message by impersonating E2Term's IP address thereby causing traffic re-direction from all E2 nodes to rogue xApp.
Rogue xApps may bypass authentication and authorization by using unsecured APIs to cause degradation in the RAN.
Adversaries may use application layer protocol on an unconventional port to avoid detection or network filtering.
Adversary sends many arbitrary but cryptographically weak SUCI values in registration requests in order to discover private key of MNO using information received from failure/success responses.
Adversary uses GTP echo request message to bypass telecom signaling application-layer firewall and so obtain and maintain unauthorized access
Adversaries may exfiltrate subscriber data by embedding it in a telecommunications protocol also used for C2 (for example GTP, SIGTRAN   or external DNS protocol).
Adversary controlled false base station transmits crafted broadcast messages to cause signaling storm on legitimate base stations
An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the UE to cause it to fail its attach procedure.
An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the AMF to cause it to fail its service or attach request.

Technique Name: DOS a UE via established GTP-U tunnel
BLUF: An adversary may send crafted GTP-U packets to a UE via established user plane to crash or slow down UE.

Technique Name: DOS a UE by GTP-U Exploit to the UPF
BLUF: Adversary sends crafted GTP-U packets to UPF in order to cause a response from a server that will crash or slow down a UE.
Adversary sends fake SBI message to NRF to de-register a legitimate NF from 5G network.

Technique Name: Unauthorized access to core network function via token abuse
BLUF: An adversary may use an OAuth2.0 token to gain unauthorized access to a network function via service based interfaces in the 5G core
Adversary exploits OAuth2.0 scope configuration using inadequate scope definitions during NF registration to gain unauthorized access to network functions in 5G networks.
A malicious rApp exploits the R1 interface to gain unauthorized access to network configuration and sensitive data by manipulating the non-RT RIC.

Technique Name: Eavesdrop on O-RAN U Plane Data
BLUF: Adversary intercepts the Fronthaul to sniff U Plane data.
An adversary may attempt to subvert the roaming authentication process by forcing the home network to derive and send keys for a victim UE
Adversaries may hide their data within a legitimate telecom protocol payload in order to evade defenses such as firewall measures
Adversary may compromise a remote management interface of routers or servers in telecommunications infrastructure to achieve follow-on behaviors
Adversaries may deploy their own software with a name to match the name of legitimate firewall utility tool
An adversary may use the identifier of a legitimate operator (PLMN ID) in order to trick the UE or evade roaming firewall/filtering
An adversary uses a wrapper  to modify the external DNS (eDNS) firewall and thus evade detection of firewall changes
An adversary may attempt to disguise communications using malware.
Adversaries may use an unconventional port to obscure illicit communications.
Adversaries may use an unconventional port to hide C2 messages.
An adversary establishes a C2 tunnel to a server it controls, using GTP-U.
Adversaries may exploit command and scripting interpreters   to abuse API to escalate privileges, navigate the control plane, discover network information, or impact availability
Adversaries may use an external proxy to act as an intermediary for network communications to a C2 server to avoid direct connections to their infrastructure
Adversaries may use an internal proxy to direct command and control traffic between two or more systems in a compromised environment
Adversaries may use an external proxy to act as an intermediary for network communications to a C2 server to avoid direct connections to their infrastructure
Adversaries may abuse credentials of default accounts set by the factory on networking devices, system assets, or user accounts to gain access or control of the host or NF
Adversaries with no prior knowledge of legitimate credentials within the system or environment may guess passwords to attempt access to accounts
Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel

Threat actors may insert malicious components, configurations, or firmware into Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) network functions during the deployment phase to gain access to radio network for further exploits
Adversaries may create or modify system-level processes to retain access, prevent detection, and open communication paths with C2 servers and new targets
